[Program 4]
[Description]
There are 2 java files in our code. Encoder.java, which is the main program, and HuffmanCode.java, which contains the implementation of the Huffman encoding that we used. We took the Huffman code from https://rosettacode.org/wiki/Huffman_coding#Java. This HuffmanCode built a tree to create an encoding.
Some changes we made to the HuffmanCode were: 1) Created hashmap to store the mappings between symbols in the alphabet and the prefixes, and mappings between 2-symbol letters and their respective frequencies (number of occurrences). 2) Changed the buildTree() implementation to account for 2-symbol prefixes. 
In our main file (Encoder.java), first we made sure command line arguments are valid, and if so, we created the necessary probabilities arrays and created testText files from the symbol's probabilities. Next, we encoded the testText file with each symbol's prefixes generated from the Huffman Encoding. We do the encoding process for both 1-symbol and 2-symbol. Then, we decoded the encoded file, for both 1-symbol and 2-symbol, and made sure both decoded files are the same as the original createText file. Finally, we computed 1-symbol and 2-symbol's respective entropies, efficiencies, and percentage differences and printed the statistics to the console.
To build/run our program, first compile with "javac *.java", then run with "java Encoder frequenciesFile k" where k is the number of symbols you wish to generate into testText

[Finish]
We finished the all parts of the assignment. testText.dec1 matches testText.dec2 which matches testText.
